title: Monday, 5th August 2019

Is it because people thought on Friday, "this is really bad" and then thought again this morning, "actually, this is really bad"?

To be sure, there's some pretty bleak strategy stuff around.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:09am

Trade tensions have pushed corporate confidence and global growth to multi-year lows. Tariffs announced on Aug 1 raise downside risks significantly. If US lifts tariffs on all imports from China to 25% for 4-6 months and China takes countermeasures, we believe we will enter recession in 3 quarters. Key points Citing a lack of progress on trade talks, the US has announced that it would impose 10% tariffs on the remaining US$300bn of imports from China from Sep 1.

BE11:09am

China has indicated it would take countermeasures. About two-thirds of goods tariffed in this round are consumer goods, which could lead to a more pronounced impact on the US as compared to earlier tranches. If these measures are implemented and stay in place for longer than 4-5 months, global growth will likely remain weak in the range of 2.8-3.0%Y in 1H20 despite forthcoming policy support. The most important area of impact is corporate confidence.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

While we don’t know the exact tipping point, we are cognizant of the risk of a potential non-linear tightening in financial conditions and its impact on capex and the labour market. As we view the risk of further escalation as high, the risks to the global outlook are decidedly skewed to the downside. If the US were to implement 25% tariffs on all imports from China for 4-6 months and China were to respond with countermeasures, we believe we would see the global economy entering recession in three quarters.

BE11:09am

Global central banks, in particular the Fed and ECB, will provide additional monetary policy support. But these measures, while helpful in containing downside risks, will not be enough to drive a recovery until trade policy uncertainty dissipates.

cracklenpop Any grey on gilts?

BE11:13am

That was unexpected: last week’s ‘hawkish rate cut’ by the Fed, and foremost escalating trade tensions prompted a sharp risk-off wave late last week. Equities, cyclical sectors, HY credit, EM assets, and other risk assets sold off substantially.
We don’t want to buy this dip though. Several factors that have kept us cautious on risk assets for the past couple of weeks are still in place:
The latest escalation in trade tensions aside, there is still a disconnect between markets – in particular risk assets – and broader macro data, as we argued in There’d better be a rebound, and as shown in charts 1 & 2. These macro factors include manufacturing PMIs, and other soft data surprises, monetary conditions in China and global trade sentiment. Our surprise diffusion indicators are – at best – giving us mixed signals, suggesting this may be too soon to raise exposure to risk assets.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

BE11:14am

Volatility and sentiment still send signals of caution: HSBC’s contrarian equity sentiment index is still in its 97th percentile vs past 5Y history. Equity vol curves also signal some complacency, and implied to realised volatilities in DM FI are still low.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

EM growth has been exceptionally weak, but capital flows have been
gathering pace. This improved access to external financing should prompt
fiscal as well as monetary easing in EM, improving near-term growth
prospects. Causality between capital flows and growth is likely both ways, but we think there is a strong case to argue that capital flows support growth.
Two additional China-related factors help to support the idea that EM growth could rise slightly. One is the support China gets from loose US monetary policy. The other is that the lags associated with Chinese policy stimulus might be coming to an end, with positive consequences for EM.
In the near term we see a kind of self-fulfilling cycle building up. Capital flows, supported by a strong push-factor, are also encouraged by the absence of large EM external financing needs, particularly in view of the 2018 ‘clean-out’ which forced a large current account adjustment on countries like Argentina, Turkey and South Africa; and may also be supported by the effect that loosening US monetary conditions have on China. All this, in turn, supports growth in the short run, and encourages investors to add risk to their portfolios.
Absent shocks from renewed trade tensions, US rate or dollar surprises, we see risks of a bubble building, particularly in view of the fact that any near-term optimism about EM growth is unlikely to be sustainable in view of the numerous threats to longer-term EM-DM growth differentials.
And because of that pessimism, it is worth paying attention to fiscal deterioration in EM: more debt today could be a problem later if growth doesn’t generate the resources to repay it.

Excel Developer #NonLinear: Here is Chris Giles of FT on the crisis, https://www.ft.com/content/1c1d5a9e-bb29-11dd-bc6c-0000779fd18c "We now understand that economies are complex, dynamic, non-linear systems in which small differences to initial conditions can make large differences to final outcomes – the proverbial flapping of a butterfly’s wings that causes a hurricane."
BE11:18am

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Looking back at 2016, markets ultimately viewed Trump’s surprising win as likely to boost growth, inflation, and interest rates. Stocks that would benefit from infrastructure spending or lower regulation outperformed.
While some aspects of the market reaction to the 2016 result might repeat in 2020, we see two key differences. First, we think divided government is likely to continue, regardless of who wins the White House. If market participants believe this, expectations of major fiscal policy changes will remain low. Second, trade policy risks are a much greater market focus today than in 2016. While we expect trade tensions with China to persist after 2020 regardless of the winner of the election, stocks that are highly sensitive to trade policy are likely to respond more strongly to the campaign and its outcome.
Using a new measure of political and regulatory exposure, we find that
nindustries that are more exposed to government policy and regulation outperformed the market following Election Day in 2016. We identify industries that we believe would be sensitive to changes in election outcome probabilities in the coming months, and we expect the relationship between politics and stock performance to strengthen as the 2020 election draws nearer.

Irish HF guy INTU at £0.41p today. I was looking at their debt levels and they account for their £375m convertible bond at fair value, which was £302m at 30.6.2019 hence keeping £73m outside of their stated debt level. Also interest rate swaps are going against them so their debt level of £4,680m is really £4,750m and add £303m for derivative financial instruments and they have really £5,053 of debt. Hence the equity value is at present £557m and going to £250m to £300m if that. I think the banks / note holders will end up owning all the shopping centres if rents keep reducing which they have been forecast to for the rest of the year. Very interesting story, which reminds me of Ireland in 2007/2008 with commercial real estate debt on shopping centres.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

HSBC has published interim results for the half year to 30th June 2019. The results themselves came in ahead of consensus expectations at both an adjusted and statutory profit level. However, the outlook is cautious and the group has also announced the surprise departure of its CEO, John Flint, who only assumed the role at the beginning of last year.

Adjusted PBT increased by 7% to $12,516bn (consensus: $12,082m) with all income statement line items ahead of expectations. Statutory PBT of $12,407bn (consensus: $11,845m) was stated after $827m of disposal gains, offset by $610 of customer redress charges (including $559m additional PPI costs) and $287m of restructuring costs. The has proposed a second interim DPS of $0.10, thus maintaining the half year pay-out at $0.20 (consensus: $0.20), along with a further $1bn share buy-back. TNAVPS ended the period at $7.19 (consensus $7.09), up from $7.01 at the end of the prior financial year.

In terms of key financial metrics, the group reported positive cost-to-income ‘jaws’ of 4.5% on an adjusted basis with the delivery of positive jaws for the full year being a key financial target (note the group missed this target last year). The reported RoTE increased by 1.5 ppts to 11.2% (consensus: 8.9%) versus the group’s target of achieving an RoTE of greater than 11% in 2020F (versus consensus of 10.1%) which remains unchanged. That said, the group is more cautious on the outlook given expectations for interest rates to fall further in the US having previously expected them to rise. As such, it no longer expects to deliver its 6% RoTE target for the struggling US business in 2020F.

The core tier 1 ratio ended the period at 14.3% (consensus: 14.3%), which compares to the group’s target ratio of 14.0%. As noted above, the group has announced a $1bn share buy-back programme which is equivalent to c11bps of core tier 1 capital and will help to neutralise the scrip.

BE11:30am

Separately, the group has announced that CEO John Flint has stepped down by mutual consent after only c18 months in the role. He has been replaced on an interim basis by Noel Quinn, current CEO of the group’s Commercial Banking operation. This is very un-HSBC like and comes as a big surprise. This suggests to us that the boardroom chemistry between the CEO and Chairman may not have been good, with the two perhaps wanting to take the group in different directions. We also note media speculation regarding a potential relationship breakdown with the Chinese authorities over the Huawei situation, albeit this could just be conspiracy theory.

For y/e December 2019F we currently forecast adjusted PBT of $23,309m (consensus: $22,034m), adjusted diluted EPS of $0.78, DPS of $0.51 and TNAVPS of $7.23. We are broadly comfortable with our above consensus forecasts given the H1 beat. At Friday’s closing price of 646p (£/$ = 1.21) and based on these forecasts, HSBC trades on a PER of 10.0x, dividend yield of 6.5% and P/TNAV of 1.1x for an adjusted RoTE of 11.1% (statutory would be slightly lower than this).

The departure of the group’s CEO after such a short time in the role comes as a major surprise and is likely to over-shadow what are a better than expected set of results. Our neutral stance on HSBC is largely a function of its valuation, especially when compared to its UK-listed peers, and it remains our view that a cheaper alternative can be constructed by owning a basket of Barclays^ (BARC, Buy at 153p), Lloyds^ (LLOY, Buy at 51p) and Standard Chartered^ (STAN, Buy at 673p). Our current fair value for HSBC is 630p (2% downside) prior to any post results update or roll-forward. HOLD

However, low interest rates and geopolitical issues (Brexit, trade war, HK, etc.) put pressure on HSBC’s outlook (as in the case of many other banks);
the bank said it will not be able to achieve its 6% RoTE target by 2020 in the US. At the same time, the CEO stepped down after 18 months, taking
everybody by surprise. At this stage, we leave our recommendations
unchanged, as the group’s strategy is unchanged.

BE11:33am

Statutory PBT of $6,194m is 10% ahead of company-consensus, with c$130m lower-than-expected exceptional items featuring $0.9bn Alawwal disposal gain, $0.6bn PPI charge and $0.2bn restructuring charge. Underlying PBT of $6,166m is 8% ahead of consensus driven by revenues 1% better, costs 1% better, impairments 18% lower than expected and associate income 12% ahead. Within revenues, net interest income is 1% ahead of consensus with the net interest margin 1bp better at 1.62% (up 3bp q/q) – supported by the Q2 rebound in Hibor (although, we note HSBC UK NIM is down 8bp q/q to 2.13%) - and loans 1% ahead and up 2% q/q, while non-interest income is 1% ahead. CET1 ratio of 14.3% is in-line, flat q/q, TNAV of $7.19 is $0.10 ahead, up $0.14 q/q.

Today’s key headline is that CEO John Flint has resigned after 18 months in the role – there’s not much detail provided for the departure and Q2 results themselves are OK. A search for his successor is under way, with Noel Quinn, head of Global Commercial Banking, having taken over as the interim Group CEO.

The outlook commentary is cautious – HSBC continues to target greater than 11% 2020 Group RoTE, but is flagging revenue headwinds from US-dollar linked interest rates, alongside geopolitical headwinds, notably trade tensions and Brexit – as such HSBC does not expect to hit 6% RoTE target in the US in 2020. Given increased risks to revenue, HSBC are executing a severance program to reduce 2020 costs (see below).

$1bn buyback looks like a miss - HSBC announce an intention to execute a $1bn share buyback, alongside the usual $0.10 Q2 ordinary dividend. We note HSBC have issued c240m shares ytd – to neutralise this impact on sharecount would cost c$1.9bn– so the Q2 $1bn buyback looks like a miss vs. the company’s stated ambition to the neutralise scrip issuance.

Pulling harder on costs – FY19 severance expected to cost c$650-700m of below the line charges and to deliver $650m-700m annualised cost savings – although it’s unclear on timing or the net effect of this on next year’s consensus - as the cost target remains positive ‘adjusted’ jaws.

BE11:35am

Slightly concerning that nothing of consequence seems to have come out of the conference call with regard the CEO going, nor the off the record spinning that follows, and that there's no apparent succession plan.

BE11:35am

Morgan Stanley:

BE11:36am

HSBC reported a solid quarter, beating on all key P&L lines. Buyback was USD 1bn and a new efficiency program was announced. Key target of greater than 11% ROTE (excluding US) by 2020e was maintained. The big move was the change of CEO, with John Flint resigning. Noel Quinn has assumed the role of interim CEO. HSBC announced that Mr John Flint is stepping down as CEO - the announcement quotes Mr Flint saying “I have agreed with the Board that today’s good interim results indicate that this is the right time for change, both for me and the Bank". The board has appointed Mr Noel Quinn (head of global commercial banking business) as interim CEO until a successor is appointed. Given the abruptness of this move, it will be the key driver of the stock in the near term, in our view. Costs: +3% operating jaws in 2Q + $650-700mn announced cost efficiencies should be taken well. Given the deteriorating revenue outlook, the cost effectiveness program is likely to be welcomed. HSBC's annual expected savings of $650/700mn (~4% of 2018 compensation cost) comes with equal 2019 severance costs (~$250mn of which were already booked in 1H). To us, there is a balance here between cost discipline, given size and complexity, and focus on long-term investments, which remain at $15bn and are primarily focused on further digitization across its businesses and further regulatory investments (B3, LIBOR, financial crime risk). Share buyback at $1bn, lower than $1.5-2bn cons. While a potential short-term negative for the share price, we fundamentally believe that banks need more, not less, flexibility in their capital return policies, given where in the cycle we are. HSBC's policy of neutralizing scrip in the medium term is unchanged. Given high dividend payout at ~75-77% in 2019/2020e, we believe it prudent to scale back the buybacks. HSBC is currently operating with ~40bps headroom to their 14% CET1 target. The $1bn share buyback consumes ~11bps off the ratio. 12M rolling EPS dilution is approximately ~1.2% vs. our previously assumed US$2bn buybacks. Outlook, reiterated at

11% ROTE by 2020 (ex US). The target for the US business at 6% ROTE by 2020e was dropped, given limited turnaround so far. Consensus 2020e ROTE currently stands just shy of 10%, given changes in interest rates and the geopolitical outlook, and structural questions on Hong Kong's economy, market and competitive shifts.We remain Equal-weight. HSBC trades on 1.1x 2019e TNAV, 11.8x PE for a 10% ROTE in 2020e, dividend yield of 6.3%.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

REITs can fall as well as plummet with INTU -44% (83% disc. to NAV, 0% divi yield) and HMSO -21% (69% disc. to NAV, 12% divi yield) last week as estate agents valuations capitulated on shop rents with 1h19 REIT earnings reversing sharply. Management's aren't so much asleep at the wheel but suffering from collective narcolepsy and the 3yr LTIP plans don't look profitable nor should they be.
There was no Boris bounce for the sector (-5.7%, UNPF -360bps) last week. The race to the bottom of lower rates (the Fed cut 25bps to 2.0%-2.25%, UK 10y gilts 0.56%) and currency (£/$ 1.21 with the BoE cutting UK GDP 2019 growth forecasts from 1.5% to 1.3% with a 33% chance of a no-deal Brexit recession) which repriced real estate and REITs in the QE years now spells rental instability with greater than 200 UK shopping centres in crisis and Grade B malls too big for their geographies and overdependent on mid-range fashion may soon be worth more as arable land. REITs are in a downward spiral: 1mth -6%, 3mth -9%, 12mth -16%, recent high 17 August -32%

den Intu Chairman - a shrewd buyer !!
BE11:49am

An optimist might be defined as a retail leasing agent who irons five white shirts on a Sunday night whilst watching reruns of 'Love Island'? In terms of the big picture, the moving parts of shopping centres valued at 4% until a few years ago will probably de-rate to 8% (a convenient illustrative round number) before reverting to fair value of 4% but only after rents have halved (again for illustrative purposes to keep the math simple).

Irish HF guy wow,John Strachan really pushing the boat all in on INTU. £33,425 BE not £3400!
BE11:50am

The key feature of HMSO and intu 1h19 data wasn't so much the falling capital values and NAVs which had been priced in, but the rental declines after flat/small falls in management guidance with intu -4 to -6% (-1 to -2% in Feb) and HMSO first missing its 2% pa rental target in 2017. The RICS retail valuation notification finally took hold and moved the estate agents from sticky sentiment to pricing in the 'Amazon effect'. The HMSO/INTU proposed merger in 2017 then had a combined book value of £10bn and is now £2.2bn. The only saving grace if it had gone ahead would be one rescue rights issue instead of two?

Irish HF guy Rents at say £100 yield 5% value £2,000. Rents fall to £50 and yields to 10% value £500 so 75% peak to trough drop, whoever can withstand that will survive.
Bluesky21 @Irish HF guy - HSBC 2018 reported total profit before tax, $19,890m, of which $17,790m from Asia
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Bluesky21 18Q4 results press release p. 7
Irish HF guy @BE, I can ship you a calculator or you can get a calculator watch, smartphone, excel or just use pen and paper!
BE11:52am

Estate agents know what cap rates trade at but less so rents. Rents can be curve balled such as intu Derby 50% sale to Cale. This preserved the book value on sale but the 1h19 valuation was -5% but INTU's economics unwound. In perspective, this trade was probably the cheapest capital the group could access and capital is the oxygen of real estate but equity and debt markets are closed to intu. CEO Matthew Roberts on the analyst call commenting on refinancing the group's £926m debt maturities in 2021 didn't seem encouraging.
Rental reductions in lease events are coming up faster than expected with HMSO £90.1m or 26% of the passing rent for break/expiry thru 2021 against ERVs of £99.2m we think are probably a sign of estate agent optimism still baked into valuations
and only retail warehouses are significantly over rented at -7.6% (probably as the business had been marketed for two years), with UK shopping centres 4.8% underrented according to Cushman & Wakefield.

BE11:52am

Going to skip a bit .....

11:53 am
BE11:53am

The crux of the HMSO predicament is that with a portfolio of fractionally-owned assets there isn't a lot of 'flex' in the business, premium outlets don't make any money and are probably crisscrossed with preemption rights (up against shareholders such as SPG and APG) and buyback clauses (we wouldn't bet against Value Retail's founder Scott Malkin having tight ownership and control contracts), so we doubt its sales/de-gearing targets are deliverable. That begs the question when did the board realise its various strategies which change as often as its dividend guidance being cut from 6%-8% to 3%-5% and now 0% pa growth was pie in the sky?
If our prognosis for multi-period slide in retail rents is correct (we have been out on a limb for 4 years despite industry brickbats) then the falling 'L' can't realistically keep pace or with the deflating 'V' in LTV. The denominator effect is therefore the balance sheet involuntarily gearing up on lower-quality assets ... and then self-inflicted dividend cuts even with appraisers Cushman & Wakefield's close working relationship having been retained as valuers reporting to the Hammerson board for the 17th consecutive year and maybe an 18th? CEO David Atkins: “We are mindful that values are still falling, so that’s why we’ve got to keep selling,” and was seeking to close a 60% gap between its share price and NAV of its properties but further disposals were likely to take “some time” because “all markets are relatively thin” (Source: The Times).

HMSO is probably seeing its equity squeezed into the SmallCap index (big assets but worth significantly less than now and a big debt burden) but probably won't get into such a parlous state as INTU. The share price at 43p is now below the nominal 50p so a capital restructuring of the share premium account would be required for the almost inevitable rights issue which seems to be priced in?
We concluded: "Cutting capex/HQ staff and selling Derby/Spain has little impact on the wall of debt and target less than 50% gearing is still too much. Peel's 27% stake risks a margin call with no div to service any financing costs. INTU is in severe financial difficulty, and may soon be an ex-REIT so opportunistic funds might be better off buying discounted malls (from the receiver) directly rather than risk the equity wrapper." We cut our PT from 59p to 44p and maintained our UNPF recommendation which has been active since August 2015 at 337p.

Here is some math to conjure with. Assume the public market is right and shares tell us where REIT portfolios are going to be marked down to. It's unlikely given the seethru yields ... but let's play make-believe as that is the consensus rule of thumb equity valuation. Deduct that from the portfolio valuations and then LTV gearing: HMSO 46% and intu 58% and on an equity basis (we are stockbrokers after all) gearing is HMSO 83% and intu 156%. That compares with FY08 of HMSO 118% and intu 200% resp. That's not just scary, it's foolhardy

Acceptable ROI bystrategicbuyerslookschallenging:We have considered potentialtradebids from both BAE and Meggitt (as perrecentpress speculation), and our workings suggest that only BAE could deliver an ROI comfortably above WACC (~10%), at the same EV (£4bn), assuming synergies of 1.5% of combined revenue (in line with recent A&D transaction comps).However, we thinkthe divestment of principallyUSelectronics assetsby BAEto Cobham during the 2000s lowersthe probabilityof an offer. On our workings, an acquisition by Meggittwould be mildly EPS-dilutive in FY19/20E, broadly at WACC and,with a higher gearing vs.peers (2.2x ND/EBITDA), looks unattractive,in our view

We have mixed views on recent developments at M&S. We remain optimistic about the turnaround potential long term, but the nearer term risk-reward profile doesn’t look very appealing. We resume coverage at Equal-weight. We remain optimistic about the long-term change story underway at M&S…Although it is not yet bearing much fruit, we continue to think that the market is underestimating the scale of the change underway at M&S and the likelihood of its longer-tem success.…but have mixed views about the new Ocado JV…

BE12:10pm

We think the logic of partnering with Ocado is compelling, but only on the assumption that M&S needs to compete in the online food channel, and we remain unconvinced by that. We believe that the switch from Waitrose to M&S supply next year carries significant risk, and do not forecast the JV hitting its contractually-embedded growth targets.…and believe that the dividend cut significantly weakens the nearer term investment case…Whilst it has been clear all along that any M&S turnaround would take several years, we had anticipated investors being well remunerated for their patience. The recent 40% dividend cut, however, undermines that thesis and also raises questions as to whether the board anticipates cashflows weakening significantly.…with more downside than upside risk over the next 12 months.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

We are not due to hear from M&S again until November, but Kantar data suggests that FY H1 LfL sales are likely to remain negative, whilst there are some obvious macro-economic risks building for the UK consumer in the second half of M&S's financial year. There is a chance that some 'green shoots' begin to emerge in 2020, but we think investor scepticism on M&S is such that the shoots will need to develop almost into fully-grown trees before the market will be prepared to price them in.We resume coverage at Equal-weight. With more than half the sell-side rating the stock at Underweight and Markit data suggesting a short base of nearly 10% (down from its peak but still well above the UK average), we think the market is already bearish enough on M&S. But, on a 12 month view, we are struggling to identify much of a Buy case either. So we resume coverage with an Equal-weight rating and a 230p price target.
